dt: {bc}to cause to turn, move, or point undeviatingly or to follow a straight course

dt.t: X-rays {wi}directed{/wi} through the body

dt: {bc}to point, extend, or project in a specified line or course

dt.t: {wi}direct{/wi} the nozzle downward

dt: {bc}to regulate the activities or course of

dt.t: {wi}directs{/wi} a staff of over 200 employees

dt: {bc}to carry out the organizing, energizing, and supervising of

dt.t: {wi}direct{/wi} a project
{wi}directed{/wi} a call center
{wi}direct{/wi} a movie
{wi}directing{/wi} a famous actor

dt: {bc}to dominate and determine the course of

dt.t: … will not find it preposterous that the past should be altered by the present as much as the present is {wi}directed{/wi} by the past.
{wi}directed{/wi} the remark to her fellow senators

dt: {bc}to mark with the name and address of the intended recipient
{bc}to adapt in expression so as to have particular applicability

dt.t: arguments {wi}directed{/wi} at the emotions

dt: {bc}to show or point out the way for

dt.t: signs {wi}directing{/wi} us to the entrance
the judge {wi}directed{/wi} the jury to acquit

dt: {bc}to act as {d_link|director|director} of a show or musical ensemble

dt.t: She both acted and {wi}directed{/wi} in the film.

dt: {bc}to point out, prescribe, or determine a course or procedure

pt: {sc}command{/sc} {sc}order{/sc} {sc}bid{/sc} {sc}enjoin{/sc} {sc}direct{/sc} {sc}instruct{/sc} {sc}charge{/sc} mean to issue orders. {sc}command{/sc} and {sc}order{/sc} imply authority and usually some degree of formality and impersonality. {sc}command{/sc} stresses official exercise of authority.
{sc}order{/sc} may suggest peremptory or arbitrary exercise.
{sc}bid{/sc} suggests giving orders peremptorily (as to children or servants).
{sc}enjoin{/sc} implies giving an order or direction authoritatively and urgently and often with admonition or solicitude.

pt.t: a sign {it}enjoining{/it} patrons to be quiet

pt: {sc}direct{/sc} and {sc}instruct{/sc} both connote expectation of obedience and usually concern specific points of procedure or method, {sc}instruct{/sc} sometimes implying greater explicitness or formality.

pt.t: {it}directed{/it} her assistant to hold all calls
the judge {it}instructed{/it} the jury to ignore the remark

pt: {sc}charge{/sc} adds to {sc}enjoin{/sc} an implication of imposing as a duty or responsibility.

pt.t: {it}charged{/it} by the President with a secret mission

pt: {sc}conduct{/sc} {sc}manage{/sc} {sc}control{/sc} {sc}direct{/sc} mean to use one's powers to lead, guide, or dominate. {sc}conduct{/sc} implies taking responsibility for the acts and achievements of a group.
{sc}manage{/sc} implies direct handling and manipulating or maneuvering toward a desired result.
{sc}control{/sc} implies a regulating or restraining in order to keep within bounds or on a course.
{sc}direct{/sc} implies constant guiding and regulating so as to achieve smooth operation.

et: Middle English, from Anglo-French {it}directer{/it}, from Latin {it}directus{/it} straight, from past participle of {it}dirigere{/it} to direct {ma}{mat|dress|}{/ma}
shortdef: to cause to turn, move, or point undeviatingly or to follow a straight course
to point, extend, or project in a specified line or course
to regulate the activities or course of

dt: {bc}to share the duties of {d_link|directing|direct:1} (something) with another or others {bc}to direct (something) jointly

dt.t: {wi}codirect{/wi} a film
{wi}co-directing{/wi} a seminar on online advertising
A couple of years ago I inherited a job {wi}codirecting{/wi} a program that integrates children's books into pediatric practice.
Carlos and Christie Vela not only co-star but {wi}co-direct{/wi}, working in tandem onstage and off.

utxt.t: {wi}codirectors{/wi} of the New York City Ballet

shortdef: to share the duties of directing (something) with another or others : to direct (something) jointly

dt: {bc}to {d_link|direct|direct:1} or manage (something, such as one's work, study, or investments) for or by oneself

dt.t: … the author discusses the basic elements and benefits of {wi}self-directing{/wi} your retirement funds.
… allowing her children to {wi}self-direct{/wi} their education, letting them decide what to learn based on their interests.

dt: {bc}to direct or guide oneself {bc}to make choices for or by oneself

dt.t: Something magical happens by letting kids {wi}self-direct{/wi}. They're happy and moving and healthy.

dt: {bc}to serve as the director of something (such as a play) in which one also performs

dt.t: … decided to {wi}self-direct{/wi} two one-act plays in lieu of the fall musical.
With their new company, they are also able to {wi}self-direct{/wi} and produce.

utxt.t: The purpose of 4-H is to help youth acquire knowledge, develop life skills, and form attitudes that will enable them to become {wi}self-directing{/wi}, productive members of society.
Creating jobs that allow for {wi}self-direction{/wi}, for independent thought and judgment, can make people more supportive and flexible at home.

shortdef: to direct or manage (something, such as one's work, study, or investments) for or by oneself
to direct or guide oneself : to make choices for or by oneself
to serve as the director of something (such as a play) in which one also performs
